Not bad but a bit too much spices for me. Hazy, deep red, beige head, good lace. Sweet, light fruity, some spices but less dominant. Nice beer.
UPDATED: MAR 4, 2012 Deep mahogany , ruby colour with a frothy off white head. Fruit aroma. rich fruit, berry malt flavour. smooth texture. Spicy finish.
Truly delicious. Nice tastes of spice, smooth - very drinkable. Highly recommended and worth seeking out.
Bottle.  Dark brown, huge brown head.  Aroma of cinnamon, raisins, dates.  taste is dark fruits and light spice, very interesting.
Unbelievably delicious. Strong and balanced with yeasts and sugars harmoniously interacting. A ridiculously delicious dark Double - one of the best beers out there no doubt.

Première fois gouter au mondial de la bière il y a 2 ans. Je lavais trouvez trop épicer. 

Maintenant, je men suis procurer une au "dépanneur le grand duc" de Longueuil espérant gouter quelque chose de différent. Et oui elle goute différent. Cependant elle est plus sec; presque pas de perception au nez, en bouche léger, très léger gout de fruit: cerise. Elle na rien a envier au bière dorigine belge du même style. Définitivement pas ma bière préférée.

Bottle from Depanneur Rahman in Montreal. Pours a mostly clear copper-brown colour, thin even layer of white head. Aroma is light molasses, raisin, coriander, dark fruits, alcohol. Well carbonated, nice palate. Simple dark fruity start, alcohol comes out a bit, rich spicy finish. Really wonderful.

Bottle. [thank you, cfrancis]
Pours deep red-brown with a large, frothy, beige-white head. Light lacings. Aroma is impressive. Coriander, light citric coffee notes, milky chocolate, caramel, raisins, cardemum. There is a medicinic hint, but it doesnt feel out of place at all. Highish carbonation, light frothy, but nice creamy mouthfeel. Flavour has good malty sweetness, chocolate, caramel, raisins. Very mild viniousness. The chocolate just gets better throughout. Coriander, mild molasses. Long, lingering mild bitter finish. Incredible dubbel, frankly.

500ml Bottle:  Aroma of dark ripe fruit, malt, light medicine, yeast, anise, slight licorice, spices, and light coriander.  Poured very deep red/ruby/brown in color with a large, loose, tan/light brown head that diminished but lasted throughout.  Very hazy.  Sparkling.  Flavor is medium to heavily sweet.  Tastes of malt, dark ripe fruit, light grape, anise, slight medicine, light licorice, spices, molasses, ginger, cardamom, slight raisin, brown sugar, candi sugar, and a hint of yeast.  Medium body.  Tingly, then slightly dry texture.  Lively carbonation.  Malt, dark ripe fruit, anise, medicine, brown sugar, ginger, molasses finish is slightly dry.  9%ABV is completely hidden throughout.

Pour is a dark brown with a large tan head.  Aroma is anise with some molasses.  Flavor is sweet brown sugar with some strong thick malts.  Finish has no alcohol and leaves a ginger on the tounge.  Good but not great and the triple Ive just had by this brewer was much better.

500ml bottle from the Fromagerie Atwater. aged 2 years and drank out of Eau Bénite chalice. pours a very dark murky brown that looks black if not in light. head is mousse like, tanned, silky, and holds throughout the beer. leaves nice lacing. aroma is dominated by dark fruits, mainly plum and raisins. lots of sweet malt flavours and yeast, perfectly balanced. full bodied and effervescent, the mouthfeel is silky on the palate and the alcohol is barely noticeable. a slight burn at the end just to let you know its there. i cant say enough good things about this brew, perfect score for me.

@Mondial de la Bière 2010, Strasbourg - slightly hazy brown colour with a poor head retention; fair aroma of ginger and marzipan; very herbal; lot of carbonation and a solid malt body; sweet and bitter; long malty spicy finish with more hoppy tones - pretty hard to drink

Very deep red pour with foamy brown head. Already excited. Aroma is fruit, butter, caramel malts, raisins. Taste is very sweet; raisins, fruit and some maltiness. Medium-large body with sticky finish. Wow.
Bottle.  This was an anise bomb seemingly.  Too sweet and overly spiced, didnt enjoy the meshing of flavors that much.  Lively carbonation, weird body, milky and thin.  Hard to drink.

500mL. Pours a clear ruby with a giant tan head. Huge lace and huge ice cream scoop retention in the center. Fresh, floral, caramel, spiced, and lightly metallic nose. Taste at first was coppery metallic. Oh dear. But as it warms, wow does this shine. Massive caramel, rich raisins, cinnamon, vanilla ice cream, tiramisu, marzipan. Big malt and spice balancing act.

What a pleasant treat this was from a bottle at Stone with my buddy Silky.  Rather inexpensive too!  Cloudy red-brown with red tints.  Light fruity sour brett nose.  Cranberry or something.  Silky bought some kimchee and fucked up my palate for the taste of it.  And the strawberry blonde hitting on him while her boyfriend was a barstool away distracted me too.  Big fizzy carb explosion.  Spicy with clove and cinnamin.  Dark fruit and grapes in the middle.  Lovely.

Tasted from bottle at Lush Roscoe.  Pours a hazy dark amber with a thick tan head that leaves a thick lace blanket over the beer.  The nose is spices and orange peel with some darker malt and leathery yeast aromas.  The flavor is fruity with orange and kumquat.  The sweet malts also come through very nicely with just a hint of light yeastiness.  The body is medium plus with lively carbonation and a long fruity finish.

Rusty penny/chestnut pour with a fluffy khaki head that left nice lacing.  Nose of spice, brown sugar, dark fruit, and molasses.  Flavor similar with lots of dried fruit, raisin, caramel, pepper, and toffee.  A little sizzly in terms of mouthfeel but its not distracting.  Really liked it.

Bottle. Pours a semi clear brown with off white head. Nose is star anise, licorice and nutmeg with Belgian yeast. Taste is strong star anise with nutmeg, licorice, spice and yeast to add to complexity.

Bottle from Archer Liquor. Pours mohogany with a goamy tan head and plum and treacle aroma. There is a spiced molasses flavor with a little candy sugar and carbonation. Tastes thin until it warms to room temperature, then the malt flavors surface.

Bottle, 9%. Interesting spicy aroma. Hazy dark brown colour, red shine. OK small light brown head. The flavour is nicely spicy, quite sweet with some dried. Has some metal flavour, would have been quite nice without it.

500 mL bottle from Dépanneur Simon Anthony in Montreal, served in a snifter. Pours clear mahogany with a tall, slightly rocky tan head. The head slowly fades to a thin cover and leaves only trace lace. On the nose, there are aromas of flowers, dark fruit, molasses, raisins, alcohol and some spice. The flavour is moderately sweet throughout with only a hint of hoppy bitterness towards the finish. The finish is long and malty. On the palate, it is medium-full in body with a smooth, milky texture and slight carbonation. Overall, this is an excellent dubbel. It has a beautiful nose and complex roasted malts. The alcohol is a bit more prominent than I would expect in a dubbel, but it is otherwise great. 2010-09-06

Gusher. Pours dark brown with shades of red. Aroma is black cherries/black berry, but was actually lighter than expected. Taste is... whaaaa!!! Again, dark fruits, but add in juniper, spices, licorice. Close to NO bitterness on this one... Only a little too sweet for its sake. Over carbonation and somewhat "bland" aroma prevents this one from being the highest rated beer on my list (at this point -- rating 138). I like dubbels, it seems. I liked Triple and their Blanche as well, but it was before ratebeer era, and no notes.

Explodes with a five+ finger light tan head that fades quickly leaving traces of lace. Cloudy deep mahogany color. Good carbonation and medium bodied.  Dark fruit nose. Flavor is dark fruit, cloves with a dry fruit finish. High ABV is hidden. $7.99 for a 500ml bottle from Beverage Warehouse Winooski, VT.

Bottle from Internet Wines & Spirits! Good folks. Buy from them. Bottle tried to exude some foam. Aroma is marvelously spicey! Color approaches ruby and the head is not big, but at least its beige going to tan. As the glass approaches the lips, juniper is all over me. Near full bodied with foamy carbonation. Flavor is spicey juniper. Hey! I love gin. Dont drink it anymore, but I love it. This stuff sort of burns the mouth with flavor. Super tasty stuff.  Get some. With the passage of half an hour, and more sipping, the juniper aspect escapes me. The lable says star anise. And I am beginning to tast liquorice. But this doesnt cause me to think less of this very tasty ale.

16.9 oz bottle.  Hazy brown with beige frosting.  Nose is raisin, fig, brown sugar and bread.  Foamy, fudgy mouthfeel with a sharp tang.  Taste is fruitcake with sour cherry, orange marmalade and cola.  Finishing dry with cinnamon and tobacco.  Maybe the best dubbel ive tried.

Bouteille 500 ml. 9%. Couleur brune foncée rubis, mousse beige. Arômes explosifs de caramel, malt, mélasse, cerise noire. Douce en bouche, malt caramel, alcool, fruits secs. Finale sans amertume et toute en saveurs. Très bonne.

500ml bottle. Seaport Beer Fest. Pours a deep amber with off-white head that leaves a great lace. Lots of stewed fruit and spice on the nose and in the mouth. Not as heavy as most dubbels Ive come across.

This was a nice nice surprise .. . pours a medium brown, good foam .. . spices are done so beautifully .. a dubbel is the norm, but add some spice and its propelled to greatness .. . would like to try more from this brewery .. . Two pretzels are walking down the street. One is assaulted. ..

Smells bretty, definitely mineralic...mixed in with that, some figs, mint leaves, papaya, spices, and some interesting funkiness.  Pours brown, nice off-white head. Effervescent body...spicy, christmasy flavors...clean, bright, sexiness in the overall profile....spices mixed suprisingly well resulting in a combination that really seems to work here.  My only problem is the severe over carbination, which makes it kind of hard to get a clean perspective of the subtle balance that I can tell is happening here.

West USA trip 2010. On bottle @ PIB. The aroma has caramel sweetness and spices. Hazy, brown coloured beer with an off-white head. The taste is sweetish, has caramel, raisins, live yeast, ginger/cardemom and clove. Quite a sparkling beer with a nice balance.

Well, for once on a Friday night I decided to take it easy and rest up for tomorrow after a long week of workin and tickin.  Of course that doesnt mean I cant get a few quick ticks in.  The first of these is somewhat of a grand slam of ticking.  Its a new high-rated beer from a brewery Ive never had in a style/country combo (Canadian Dubbel) that Ive never had.  Tick, tick, tick.  Lets see what this beer is all "aboot" (zing!), shall we?

This 50cl bottle from K&L Redwood City pours a deep, clear mahogany color with reddish hues and a lasting tan head with large bubbles.  Good lacing.

Great, interesting aroma.  Spicy - cardamom stands out - with molasses, anise, sweet caramel malt, and dark fruits.  Smells really great.

Flavor is good with a lot of interesting stuff going on.  A little sweet for the style, which I didnt mind not too long ago but is now a minor detriment.  Spicy with toffee, plum, fig, raisin, licorice, molasses, and yeast.

Very nice mouthfeel.  Tingly with high carbonation and medium body.  No real booziness despite the 9% ABV.

Pretty good stuff overall.  A unique and interesting take on the style, and a thoroughly enjoyable beer.
Bottle sampled at SIB, pours cloudy dark orange. Aroma and flavour of figs, dates, caramel malts, spices and Belgian yeast. Lots of carbonation - very smooth. Excellent.

I suppose I realized that this was a belgian double when I bought it, but it really didnt taste like one. strong berry, maybe cherry? aroma right off the bat, spice and orange flavor and a great malt/hop balance. i really didnt know what to expect from this one, was a crapshoot when i bought it and i was very pleasantly surprised.

Bought this one in bottles, and sampled the first time at the pub itself. Poured a dark purple-red colour with red highlights. The head was beautiful, tanned, creamy, had excellent retention and great lacing. Got a blueberry scent at first, then turned into spices and Belgian yeast. Very, very smooth mouthfeel with not even close to a burn. The taste had good fruit with some strong bite. Berries lingered into the aftertaste. Just like all the other Vobiscum brews, this one is excellent.

bottle.  a clear ruby brown under a huge, loud, foamy yellowish head.  fruity aroma of peach and pear.  flavor of pear, apricot, apple, caramel.  a bit tart.  annoying sharp carbonation creates a foamy mouthfeel.  full body.

Large tan head, overcarbonated. Fair retention and a skimpy lace. Lightly hazy brown color with a nice red glow about it. Fruity esters, faint bananna, licorice, co2 and dark malts. Body is medium and a tad spritzy for my likes, a hint oily. Plummy dark fruit flavors, some raisin, cola, lightly sweet malts, yeasts and light chocolate notes. Lightly sweet fruity burpy finish. A bit over carbonated. Bottle thanks to Robert from statelineliquors.

Liquide brun rouge avec une mousse solide qui colle aux parois du verre.  Le nez est dominé par des épices.  Difficile de faire un choix derrière lanis : girofle?, poivre?, muscade?  On note aussi la présence évidente de fruits foncés et de bonnes traces de cassonade.  En bouche, le liquide libère des saveurs de malts doux, de levure, de petits fruits et toujours cet étalement dépices.  Sous le palais, le liquide pétillant est de moyenne corpulence et sa texture est veloutée.  Aucune trace du 9%.  En résumé, double complexe et particulière.

Pours dark mahogany with pillowy tan head.  Immediate aromas of sweet fruit, including cherry and plum, raisin, brown sugar, bready malts, and Belgian yeast.  Prickly carbonation.  Flavor is nicely balanced, with sweet brown sugar, raisin, apple, and cherry notes complimented by bread and light licorice.  I picked this up on a whim while on vacation in Montreal, and this makes for a very pleasant surprise.

UPDATED: FEB 5, 2012 -re-rate - A bit earthy-mineral, salty, even a bit meaty, dark fruit with just a trail of hop bittering, aromas a bit wild. - orig notes - Licorice and rootsy spice, yeasty and cakey sweetness, some top of lemon, Aroma anise seed honey which plays into flavor. very interesting. Thanks Douggie!

Pours a dark mahogany colour with a big frothy tan head. Aroma is of grainy malts, and a little herb and spice. The taste is sweet and malty. Medium bodied, somewhat oily on the palate with lively carbonation. Overall a very good beer.

Pours dark brown almost black. With a thicck foamy head and great lacing. Aroma is great! Bold and big with notes of locorice and malt. Flavour is very full and unique. Lotts of licorice on the palate some notes of fruit and malt. This is a very complex beer with many deep layers one hell of a brew!

Biscuity malt aroma, a bit of alcohol. Dark brownish-red hues, great head and lacing. First taste is of yeast, then the malts and the sweetness. Fairly sweet and clean tasting after the yeast fades quickly, finishes with a lot of bubbles and a gradual fade out of the mixed flavours. Nice and peaky, but the bubbles yeast and alcohol seem to overshadow the malts.
UPDATED: MAR 23, 2010 The aroma is sweet and malty. The brown color could have more head on it. The sweet malt flavor is smooth and creamy on the palate, big notes of caramel amd black licorice.

Bottle. Exuberant pour, with an enormous brown finely bubbled head resting atop a deep mahogany body. Initial aromas are surprisingly perfumey and delicate with underlying sweet dark fruits. As the head settles, it releases much more spice. The flavours are spectacular: sweet dark figgy fruit, interesting spices that wrestle with delicate floral perfume, sweet cinotto-like notes, really really interesting without comprising the styles identity. Not a hint of its 9% strength! A beautiful dubbel.
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text: Bottle from MartinT!   Pours a dark tea brown with a dense tan head that doesnt quit.  Fine spray of tan lacing from lapping waves of beer on sides of glass.  Nose is lightly earthy and has hints of anise. Body is large and super sweet.  A wonderful warmer to prepare for the coming storm with.  Mouth feel is quick and finish ends abruptly.. No lingering overbearing tastes.  Alcohol presence is known but it is not unruly or unwelcome. Nice.

Inviting scent of liquorice, treacle and some lovely malt, deep murky brown, small tan head. Flavour has a milder level of anise, than the nose. Medium bodied, balanced, quite unique for a dubbel(liquorice/anise?) Terrific twist!
A brown beer with white head. An average carbonation. Spices and caramel lead the aroma and the taste. Really well balanced.

La mia prima birra canadese...manco una Labatt avevo mai bevuto.

Abbondante schiuma giallo-ocra.Colore marrone scuro con riflessi ambrati.Aroma molto speziato, con noce moscata, zenzero, anice e cannella.Dolce, piccante,laroma con le stesse spezie elencate prima, e in aggiunta il pepe e il coriandolo.E certamente molto piccante e molto dolce. Buono il corpo, abbastanza liscia quasi densa. Una gran birra davvero!!!

Huge yellow-ochre head, lacey, over deep brown-amber beer with orange sides and tiny, but visible UFOs. Very spicy aroma, with nutmeg, ginger, aniseed and cinnamon. Dark malts, but sweet. Sweet, spicy. Bit of all the above spices from the nose, plus pepper and coriander. This simply is liquid  speculoos. Its certainly VERY spicy and VERY sweet. Well to very well-bodied, quite slick to the point of oily. Maybe just a tad more reticence might have benefitted it. OTOH, this is also a statement against dullness. I like the  au goût évolutif  Now where did I hear that one before?  Grand merci à Sylvain et compadres!

5 months old bottle from depanneur Primeau. Pours a dark mahogany with high carbonation. Lucious head, spicy aroma with some meaty notes, hard to describe but very pleasant. Taste is complex with lots of spice and a very sweet finish even though this is highly attenuated. ABV a little bit high for the style but, hey, who cares, this is tasty and worthy of cellaring a few years for sure!

Bottle thanks to Glouglouburp!Hazy mahogany, fluffy beige head. Nutty nose reminiscent of Westy 8 but for less depth and the additional pepper and light orange. Sweet body of chocolate, nut, and hints of citrus and yeast. Dry finish, overly-carbonated but with a very refined and subtle nut finish emerging behind the orange. Though nothing stands out, very enjoyable combination of elements.
Light brown coloured beer with a huge white head and no carbonation. A spicy aroma. Medium wattery palate with some malty touches. Finish is sweet with a real sugar ending mixed with some spices.
Spicy aroma with licorice, cloves, citrus. Pours a clear amber- brown with tan head. Dominant spice with licorice and fruity sweetness.

Poured out a very clear light mahogany with a thin skiff of white bubbles hanging out. The aroma on the mellow side but that isnt to say that what I have here isnt pleasant. An interesting mix of mulled spices, cinnamon, coriander, cloves, candied orange peels, allspice. The allspice is the dominant contributor... man, there is a lot of it. Dark sweet fruits and a very late caramel malt. I love this aroma! The taste is similar to the aroma. Immediate allspice and cloves that never leave the mouth until finally fading into a lengthy aftertaste. More candy, the zing of peppermint without the flavour, cinnamon, red ripe berries, stiff raisin, I keep thinking chocolate (but it seems odd here although I wont rule it out), floral breath, licorice (finally!). Hell, this beer is the shit! Every sip snaps my taste buds to attention. The mouth feel is thick with lots of different things loitering during different sips. Great after taste. No hint of 9% at all. This is an exceptional brew with no flaws except for the fact that I cannot buy it here. Slides in to my top beers with class and ease.

Deep rich mahogany red color, luxurious creamy tan head. Spicy, malty aroma, coriander, bubblegum, cloves, allspice? Piquant spice flavor on a round malt base. Medium carbonation keeps it from feeling too heavy. More enjoyable and interesting than Ommegangs take.
Bottle thanks to Fred82 - Spicy malt nose, taste is much the same.  Somewhat full palate that is very pleasing.  A little fruit taste lingers in your mouth makes the experience very pleasant.

Bottle (Thanks Mikkel) - shared with Mette, Kasper, Jørgen & Jesper. Cloudy brown - white head. Spicy, high malty, chocolate, ryebread, berries, licorice, dried fruity, roasted, anis, light sweetnes, honey. Nice.

Bottle thanks to Dakine and Dany.  Pours a very deep, almost brown, clear amber with super thick tan head.  Head is really creamy and leaves lots of lacing.  Aroma is very sweet with tart and dried fruit, lots of spice, yeast, and clove.  Flavor matches well and improves as temperature rises.  First half of glass made me think I wasnt enjoying it, last half was very nice.  It definitely comes together nicely and the fruity nature really sets it apart.  Mouthfeel is slightly slick and heavy bodied.

Bottle at Nørrebro Bryghus, thanks to Theis and Mette.
Cloudy orange coloured with a small off white head.
Sweet and fruity aroma of fruits, dried fruits, spices, anise and liquorice.
Sweet and fruity flavour of dried fruits, spices and liquorice.
Spicy finish.

50 cL bottle, courtesy of Theis and Mette. Pours hazy dark orange to brown with a small white head. Aroma is solid coriander and annis spiced, roasted caramel and yeasty. Sweet caramelish malt flavoured and spiced. Smooth annis seed note alongside coriander and caramel into a mild finish.
Pours bright mahogany into a Trappist glass. Fizzy cola head with little retention. Dusty pit fruit aromas. Crisp with dried fruit from front to back.

Acheté Dépanneur chez Gibb à Évain. En bouteille. 9%. Odeur dépices, de réglisse noire et de caramel au beurre. La couleur est brune opaque. Présence dun large col beige mousseux avec une large dentelle sur le verre. Goût dépices, de caramel avec une pointe dagrumes. Durée moyenne de larrière goût. Le corps est plein avec une texture crémeuse. Moyenne effervescence en bouche. Légère présence de raisin en arrière goût.

Bottle. Orangepeel fizzlestick nose.
Cloudy brown, huge creamy head.
Big hops, citruspeel and lemon up front, flowery, bergamotte ?
A dubbel ipa, very nice
Foamy mouthfeel.

500 ml bottle shared by jessem. thx jesse. pours ruby with a big lingering tan head. aroma of spice, dark fruit, and floral hops. the flavour is huge and complex. spice, dark fruit, yeast, hops. really stageringly good. this one really stands out from other quebec made belgian inspired ales. it has that extra layer of craftmanship that you usually only find in trappist offerings. id love to get more stuff from this brewer. thx for the share jesse.

Aroma: I get pumpkin, spice (corriander, cloves), a bit of citrus, apple,  a "smell" of acidity a bit of yeast, grape. Appearance: dark brown with a fading head that leaves a thin cream head behind. Taste:  light acidity, fruity punch very sweet (unaged bottle) grape like almost wine, ripe fruits. Finale like a blanche, spices take over the fruits a little coriander not too sure of all these spices that come back after the fruit have left.

500mL bottle I got in Gatineau at Marche Jovi, drunk with matt7215 at an afternoon tasting. Pours a very nice deep hazy maroon with a large beige head. The nose on this one is just outstanding, one of the best smelling beers Ive had in recent memory. Lots of spice, cardamon, corriander, clove, Earthy, sweet dark malts, minor fruity esters, not much of a Quebecois character to it in my mind. Very vibrant and floral, I could sniff this for hours. Flavour matches up nicely, very sweet upfront with accompanying spice and some dryness. Esters are minimal but the malty aspects are very satisfying. Does not feel like a 9% beer at all (Im sure if properly tested it most likely is not). Reminds me of Chimay Blue, but Im much more impressed with this than I ever have been with that Chimay. Very glad I picked this one up! Bravo!

Brown pour with reddish tints and a one finger beige head that dissipates slowly. Aroma is loaded with yeasty clove banana spice, caramel malt, and dry citrus. Flavor is very fruity, spicy and sweet. Flavors are pronounced, powerful, and hard hitting. Lots of citrus and clove complemented by citrus, plumb, and sweet nectar. Palate is soft and caressing in its above average carbonation. Finish is dry. Perhaps the best of the style Ive had to date.

dark mahogany with a solid white head, good lacing. Aroma holds lots of spice, sweet malt. Flavor is excellent, on another level from the aroma- tons of plum, cherry, raisin, clove, cinnamon, and belgian spiciness. Palate is also great; sticks with a nice sweetness that has a lighter fruitiness to it. Really superb dubbel.

mahogany pour with nic eone finger head.  spicey malt aroma, brown sugar.  Mouth is intensely spiced.  I cant stop drinking it.  Very good spice and flavor.  dark fruit upfront and cinnamon then light fruit, nectar, at the finish.  Drinkable and delicious

Bonus from boutip. Shared by Wee heavySd and his gf cyn. dark copper colored with a nice tan head, sweet malty nose flavor was also sweet with some belgina spicy yeastyness. finish was smooth and sweet but well balenced. a nice drinkable dubbel.
copper pour, aroma of sweet, ripe fruit, candi sugar, and some yeasty malt. Flavor is VERY spicey, cloves, and cadamon, with some sweet malt in the finish. very nice sipper of a double.
Bonus from boutip. Shared with bikesandbeers and my gf cyn. Pours orangey brown with a tan head.  Nose is sweet and malty.  Taste is sweet and rich and all in all very good.

.5 liter bottle.  Pours a dirty deep copper amber with a massive head and streaky lace.  Aroma is real nice- they got the balance here- good smooth fruity esters, belgian yeast, and spicy phenolics mixed with a really nice deep toasted fresh bready malt character.  Flavor is mostly sweet, but not artificial- light candi sugar, and tons of big cara pils malt sweetness, caramel, toffee, and molasses, and fruity belgian yeastiness.  Smooth finish and easy drinking.  I dont like dubbels, but this was very enjoyable.

Bottle with thanks to Boutip.  Pour is a mahogany brown with a massive head.  Aromas are dusty, yeasty and slightly spicy.  Flavor is very sweet brown sugar & maple syrup, figs & dates, cloves and vanilla.  Mouthfeel is fairly thin
user_location: The Wet Side of a Dry Town, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Shared by MatSciGuy, this is one of the best dubbels I have had in a long time.  Cloudy, light brown color.  Thick, white, rocky head.  Lots of yeast.  Medium sweet, with loads of malt and fruit flavor.  Light spice.  Very well done.

Bottle thanks to Daknole. Cloudy burgundy brown with nice beige head. Aroma hints of pedio. Below that its fine, lots of spices, like clove, anise, date sugar, and vanilla bean! Smooth and creamy mouthfeel. Flaovrs parallel the aromas nicely: again with the hint of pedio sitting on top of the spices. Cinnamon comes out more in the flavors and the finish is tannic but also gingerbready. Very nice.

Dark brown, somewhat cloudy and with s a low head.  The aroma is somewhat similar to salmiakki with a herbal (thyme?) accent.  Really fun nose.  Big, chewy, liquoricey double.  Very complex.  Nice body.  One of the best doubles Ive had.

Glouglouburp on the hook up again!!  Reddish brown pour with an off white head.  The nose is awesome!  Full of cardamom, star anise cloves and nutmeg.  Flavor follows suit with the same spices and reminds me of a ginger peach tea I have had before...fun beer and damn good!

Pours dirty brown with thin tan head. The aroma is sweet and hinting at malts to go along with spices like cinnamon and nutmeg. Interesting. The taste has bright notes of apples, spices and a sense of pepper. I really cant wrap my palate around this brew and put words to the flavor notes.  Hmm.

Bottle, courtesy Retorp. Translucent copper brown pour, thick head and thick lacing. Big fruity nose, very spicy, cotton candy, some slight heat. Flavor is spicy with lots of complexity, creamy Belgian yeast, cotton candy and bubble gum. Medium-bodied, very balanced.
Bottle from Glouglouburp. Thanks Dany! Red copper color with huge off white head. Spicy aroma. Tastes of sweet malt, chai spices and vanilla. Good.

Bottle courtesy of the tasting group.  Pours amber-red with an off-white head.  Nose is big dark fruit with spice, some chocolatey notes, and roasted malt.  Flavor is much the same with some noticeable alcohol and sugary touches.  Tasty, medium-bodied beer.

UPDATED: JAN 24, 2010 Very spicy for a beer of this kind.  The sweetness is well hidden but there is some unpleasant sourness to me in the taste.  Tongue tingling.  Ill see what my cellar will do with the two other bottles.  Right now (this bottle had been cellared for 6 months), its not bad but thats about it for me. 7-4-7-3-14 ADDED:  Wo!  With a little aging (a year and a half), this becomes totally mellow and candyish, spicyness is more in balance and this is very enjoyable. OK!  Rating would be 8-4-8-4-16 if it was like that when fresh...  Ok, Letss be nice...

Bottle from glouglouburp, thanks Dany. Pours all head to the point that I thought this might have been infected. Well it wasnt just not good. Both the flavor and aroma were super sweet like a combination of artificial sweetner bubble gum and chai tea leaves, not a good combo. Not sure how I did it but I finished the bottle.

Bottle thanks to Dmac, "Laval" written in marker on the label...know Mario Lemieux is from there so hopefully this one is great. Pours out a slightly ruby hued brown with a moderate off white head. Aroma is big on the fruit, some spice and maybe more sweetness and a touch of bazooka gum. Taste is very sweet, apricot, bubblegum, some more fruits and a sweet/slightly alcoholic finish. Not bad, but too over the top sweet.

500ml bottle from La Barik, 3-riv in trappist glass, cellar temp. Huge big brown fluffy head. Dark brown color. Nice rich awesome aroma. Dark fruits, hints of alcohol and sweetness. Some carbonation on the tongue causing a light bite ! Leaves the tongue dry. Quite heavy and rich taste. Only downside is the stong presence of alcohol. Overall awesome beer, well crafted but could benifit from a bit more balance. Rating #33

500 ml bottle from Marche Jovi, served at cellar temperature in a tulip glass. JA07/09.
App.:  Very deep mahogany with a large light tan froth.
  
Aroma:  Big gobs of chewy malt  brown sugar, molasses, lots of dark dried fruits, a touch nutty and woody, reminiscent of dark rum and of rootbeer, some lighter, tangier fruits such as cherries, pink bubblegum esters, rich and inviting.
  
Palate:  Medium-full body and relatively soft carbonation, slightly powdery?
  
Flav.:  Much like the nose  the malts are a little more severe with a slightly biting burnt sugar note, still lots of brown sugar and molasses, somewhat less fruity, a bit heavier on the minty rootbeer, still some sour cherries, the esters come in later; sweet but with sufficient tang and bitterness (though low) for balance.

I love the DV line!  Beautiful stuff!

Bottled.  Poured cloudy medium brown with an active, sticky, well-retained cap of tan head.  The aroma picked up sweeter toasted caramel, dry chocolate, and toffee with fruity yeast and woodsy notes giving a warm accent.  The flavor had aged caramel, chocolate, and fruity notes at the dry, slightly toasted core with more yeasty notes surrounding.. warm overall with a slightly sweet bend to it.. very, very tasty!  Medium-bodied and expertly balanced on the palate riding on lively carbonation.. spicy and drier at the finish.  Excellent stuff!

Bouteille brune, 500ml, achetée à La Trappe à Fromages de Hull il y a un mois.  Servie dans un calice trappiste.  Nez très invitant évoquant les agrumes, les épices et un soupçon de beurre de caramel, le tout très bien dosé.  Cest prometteur !  En apparence, le liquide est très foncé, mais devient rouge ambré sous la lumière.  Une mousse crémeuse et persistante sagrippe au verre.  En bouche, cest très rond et crémeux.  Curieusement, cest peu sucré pour une double dabbaye.  On remarque davantage le côté épicé/levuré.  On ressent aussi une sensation agréable sur la langue et un léger picotement probablement dû au haut taux dalcool (9%) et à une légère amertume de houblon.  Le post-goût est surtout marqué par la levure et une infime pointe danis étoilé.  Somme toute une bière un peu bourrative, mais qui se savoure lentement seule ou en accompagnement dun copieux repas.

[1772-20081013] 500mL bottle. Spicy light fruit aroma has mild allspice. Hazy, dark amber red body with a long-lasting creamy light tan head. Spicy light fruit continues in the flavour with mild alcohol and allspice. Medium body. Boozy but nice. (w/ jerc, tuqueboy)
UPDATED: APR 23, 2009 Belle couleur, légère dentelle, senteur dalcool, goût de cerise. Un vrai rafraichissement.

500 ml bottle courtesy of glouglouburp. Appearance- dark ruby red, good clarity. Huge head, four fingers at least. Minimal lacing, just a soapy head patty in the middle of the glass. Nose- really spicy, licorice. Taste- big spice presence, various spices (clove,cinamon anise), dark and citrus fruits, light roast and sweet finish. Very complex. Mouthfeel- medium, low carbonation. Drinkability is good.

Dégusté avec Pyrozoid. Couleur cuivré foncé avec reflet ambré... bonne mousse beige.  Arome de zest dorange et lime, canelle, mince filet de clou de girofle, caramel, levure et vanille.  En bouche... un peu sallé, bonne et légère amertume, crémeuse et finition sucré.  Gout de beurre, caramel, canelle, clou de girofle avec un peu de menthe en poste gout.

Bouteille de 500 ml. Dégusté avec french tickler. Biere de couleur brune foncé brumeuse avec un bon collet collant. Odeur tres fleural, malt et un peu de vanille. Gout de clou de girofle, sucre et sel en meme temps, radis et un peu de vanille qui sort.

UPDATED: JAN 9, 2009 Dégusté dans un verre tulippe entre 4 et 10 degré celcius. Bière brun foncé ambré avec reflet orangé cuivré. Bonne mousse de couleur caramel doux. Senteur de malt, de pelure dorange, dalcool, danis, de canelle, de lactose, de vanille et de banane verte vers la fin. Ronde et crémeuse en bouche avec amertume moyenne. Un goût de clou de giroffe, de sucre brun et de caramel au beurre légèremment poivré.

[Bottle] Pours a cloudy brown with a medium large head of small brown bubbles that lingers. Aroma is lots of spices - cinnamon, clove, nutmeg, and a touch of fruitiness. Flavor is nutmeg, lots of black licorice, cinnamon, and a fruity finish. Alcohol is only evident by the warming feeling in the back of my throat, but is quite nice. Leaves a touch of tartness on the sides of the tongue as well.

Thanks MartinT! This beer was fantastic! Poured hazy dark brown body, huge beige froathy head what diminishes slowly. Spicy aroma with vanilla, milk chocolate, clove and cinnamon, fine dried fruits. Complex aroma and a rich flavor! Fantastic fruity mouthfeel, well hidden alcohol. Chocolate and vanilla, sweet caramel malt with fine roasted grains, nice spicies like clove and cinnamon. Nice hop pushes through the finish,  aftertaste is complex like the flavor. I love this beer!

Bottle.  Pours brown with a frothy cream head.  Aroma of clove, milk chocolate, esters, and dark fruit.  Flavor has subdued sweetness, with some underlying hop character.  Beautiful creamy and complex flavors fun throughout this beer.  I tasted yeast, chocolate, clove and dark fruit in there, all blended very well.  Charlevoix doesnt try to do anything flashy with this brew, just sticks to basics and produces a handsome beer.  For $3.99 Canadian, this is a real steal.

In short: An herbal and spicy (cloves mainly) belgian dark ale. Very good. How: Bottle 500ml, many many many times. This rating for a 1 year old bottle The look: Cloudy dark burgundy body topped by a persistent large beige head In long: Nose is floral and spicy with tulips, lilacs, cloves and other herbs. Taste is more of the same. Well malted, yeasty, fluffy but overall a bit too much on the spicy/floral front. Caramel and toffee almost harmoniously blend-in with the cloves and overall herbal/spicy nature of the beer. For the style this beer offers very little in the way of fruity flavours. I think there has been more than one batch of this beer because I remember having it less spicy. As many of the past ratings testify Ive been sending a lot of these across the border and got a lot of credits for that, and with the current economic situation thats about all the credit I can get these days.

UPDATED: JUN 5, 2013 500ml from Glouglouburp - thanks, Dany! Very nice pour, hefty and deep ruby/brown with a very full carbonation, lively and lasting with a foamy head. The nose is scrumptious, fruity, pert and spicy hops, with a slight musk in there. Full mouthfeel with the dark fruits dancing on the tongue and a rather lengthy, just slightly dry finish - heavy autumnal vibe, like dried leaves with some herbs and spices. Really very fine.
My favorite of the night.  Lots of dark fruits and some spice on the aromas.  Flavors of more spice and caramel flavors.  I actually think I got some spearmint in that aroma.  Nice beer.

UPDATED: OCT 18, 2010 500ml bottle shared by fordest(thanks). Pours a translucent copper color with a small white head. The nose is distinct with aromatic herbs, spices and a bit of malted grain. The spices really rule in this brew, nearly all the dubbel character is hidden, cloves and mint leaves dominate the flavor set in a malt backdrop. The mouthfeel is silky with lively carbonation. The finish is long with lingering mint. Overall: It must have taken a lot of experimentation for the brewer to come up with this one, and they pulled it off. A winner.
Bottle shared by fordest at his house. Sweet carmel malt flavor with some spices and fruit. Interesting and very good.
Bottle, awesome art btw.   Pours an amber brown body with white head.  Sweet cinnamon and nutmeg.  Belgian spices.  Sweet malty with tons of spices.  Good beer.

Courtesy TheCheeseMan.  Mostly clear copper-brown color, thin even layer of white head.  Light molasses, raisin, coriander, dark fruits, alcohol.  Well carbonated, nice palate.  Simple dark fruity start, alcohol comes out a bit, rich spicy finish.

This beer is in my top 5.... the color is fantastic... a dark red... the nose is very complex... in mouth!!! WOAH!!! the alchool is very present... a bit of black licorice... and a little toutch of spices... Cheers

Un cas unique.  Le nez est exceptionnel.  Pas réussi a identifier les aromes...Sambucca...épices...corriande...Tout comme le gout d’ailleurs!   L’ alchol se fait plutot discret.    Un must pour les amateurs de produits high class.

Humongo-head, dark brown body, spicy scent.Huge sweetness, enough to be distinctive and not disgusting, balanced by impressive hop finish. Somewhat oily texture. Massive notes of Blue Curacao, brandy, Grand Marnier and some spiciness (from the yeast?). Sheets of lacing left on the glass. Very complex and interesting.

500ml bottle from glouglouburp. Pours dark brown with a good sized, crisp off-white head. Smells nice, mellow dark fruity, yeasty, not overly sweet. Tastes dark fruity raisiny, malty as well and bready yeasty. It has kind of marshmallowy sugary sweetness, slight chocolate. Medium body, vibrant carbonation.

Robust mahogany glow and a brimming cap of beige, succulent and full.  Aroma of baked pears and apple fritters dappled in tarragon, cloves, mint and cinnamon.  Vibrant yeasts.  Doughy malts linger with a caramelly, dense sweetness beneath a quaint floral dusting of rose or lavender.  A bit of anise, pit fruits, and brown sugar.  The intrigue is infatuating here, as this dusky-herbal sensation of leafy spice and flowers brings it to a fairytale world of fresh meadow springtime.  But its distant, not immediate, and thats what makes it irresistable.

Flavor seems a mite sweeter, polishing that anise note into a fuller chewiness of licorice amidst a lot of brown sugar, raisin bread and fig.  Mexican chocolate, mostly bitter, black tea leaves, pear skins, bubblegum; complexity on a delirious parade.  Mid palate bittersweetness of pear skins and a return of that floral-herbal essence tempers the tendency toward oversweetness rather nicely, with little room to spare.  Duskiness of dry, earthy hot spice toward the end.  Somewhat reminiscent of curry in a strange and pleasing way.  
Body is medium to full and briskly carbonated, but never airy, which really fits my taste for this style perfectly.  Finishes with some deep fruitiness of fig and melon, then lingers on a musty, sweet molasses and licorice flavor, quite richly.  Lasting impression is of a very slightly overexcited sweetness, though the moments of brilliance in this fine example are uniquely memorable and fulfilling.  Thanks Dany!

Bottle Cloudy, dark, almost impenetrable, brown ale (nice copper hue when held up to the sun) with a huge, frothy, beige head. Incredible retention. Yeasty nose with touches of licorice and mint. Full-bodied, but a touch thin, with fizzy carbonation. Sweet and a smidge on the hot side. Otherwise, dark fruits, licorice, molasses and winter spice. Moderately bitter, lightly sweet, mildly acidic, licorice finish. Kudos to glouglouburp for floating this one my way!

bottle thanks to glouglouburp! pours dark brown with creamy foamy off biege head. aroma of figs, yeasty, cloves, cardamom, vinous, rose, licoricie, bubblegum. lots going on in the nose. flavors of licorice, caramel, figs, bubblegum, dark candy sugar, cloves, and dough. thin body. one of the better dubbels ive had but a bit too sweet to be perfect.

Bottle from Glouglouburp. Word. This is an awesome dubbel. Pour is dark brown with a beautiful, firm tan head. Full aroma of plum, fig, yeast, cumin, and lavender. Or something. Dought flavor, very dry, tons of dark fruit. Everything here comes together perfectly. The only other dubbel Ive had that can go toe to toe with this is the Midnight Sun. All else pale.

Great looking beer.  Dark chestnut color and  a creamy tan head.  Quite spicy nose, but the spice in the flavor is not too intense.  Sweet, spicy flavor with a lengthly yeasty banana finish.  This beer is delicious.

Bottle. Dark brown with a medium foamy head. Aroma is roasted malts, spices, mint, brown sugar, yeast and a touch of alcohol. Flavor is sweet malt, a lot of spices, a healthy dose of mint, yeast and some hops. Full bodied with medium carbonation. Another very good brew from Charlevoix.

Full spice rack aroma.
Nutmeg, warming ginger, cough syrup (euchaluptus), cherries.

Big yellowish beige lasting head. Deep amber body with carbonation. Harmonic spicy, herbal aroma of cardamom, ginger, muscat, anise, and a pile of other spices. Dry-sweet intensely spicy taste with much the same character, but also malts, fruit, and banana. Dry feeling settles in the mouth. Very impressive for the clarity and distinctness of the taste and aroma, which is at the same time extremely harmonic. Tastes like a spice garden. Im deeply impressed. (0.5l bottle traded from glouglouburp.)

UPDATED: OCT 20, 2010 Pours a dark brown with a small foam ring. Aroma of concorde grapes, garam masala, and sweet port - nice! Taste does not disappoint - Hops, alcohol, tart and vinous with a satisfying spicy (again with the curry) finish which lingers.Maple syrup, munich malt. Good carb! Thin but ok body, grape-juice mouthfeel after swallowing. This beer is complex - warms the stomach, satisfying, and a good conversation piece. Thanks to Boutip for the trade!
Pours brown with a tan head.  Smells very fruity with some mulled spicy undertones and some tartness.  Tastes of cherries, spices, sugary.  Interesting.

500 with thanks to after4ever! Pours a hazy dark brown with a persistent off-white head. Aroma of nuts, fruit and licorice. Medium body and carbonation. Sweet apple and licorice taste with a spicy finish.

UPDATED: MAR 10, 2008 Bouteile 500 ml. Mousse typique des bières Belges, cest à dire très très abondante. La couleur est semblable à une scotch ale ( foncée avec des reflets rubis) Au nez, la bière dégage beaucoup darôme ( Anis,Citron, pamplemousse, levures, alcool ) En bouche on goûte dabord  lalcool qui laisse place aux épices et qui termine par un mélange dalcool et de caramel.

500 Thanks, glouglouburp! Murky dark brown with bright ruby highlights. Thin gray film. Enormous sweet natural licorice nose. Medium body, rich carb. Thick and chewy flavor without having a thick and chewy body. Plums, licorice, and more licorice with a long licorice finish. Its very difficult to convey with words how delicious this beer is for essentially having one flavor in it.

500 mL bottle.  Dark, dark ruby brown, with a small beige head.  Smells more like a wit than a dubbel, with lots of fresh, sweet orange and spice.  The citrus fades in the flavour, but the (brown) spice remains where it is joined by some licorice, alcohol, and caramel.  Not much fruit - maybe some apple.  No candi sugar.  Body is decent, carbonation good, the finish somewhat grainy (feel).  Above average.

Pours a dark brown with a tan head. Aroma is mostly sweet fruit. Tastes of caramel, dark fruits, spice, candied sugar. Finishes with a cotton candy taste. Palate is mostly creamy with a light carbonation feel.

500 ml. bottle. The color is dark brownwith a beige head. The taste is sweet caramel, fruits and malt. This is a very good Belgium style beer from one of the best if not the best microbrasserie in Quebec.

Bouteille brune de 500 ml. Mousse abondante et qui tient bien. Belle robe brune aux reflets orangés et tirant sur le pourpre.Nez dominé par le caramel et le raisin. Goût et arrière-goût dalcool et de caramel avec une légère présence de raisin. Se rapproche dune scotch ale. Très bonne bière.

UPDATED: JAN 9, 2010 bouteille brune 500ml.

"Bière inspirée de lhétitage monastique belge", mentionne létiquette. je nai malheuresement pas souvent vue des bières dabbaye brune double aussi forte en alcool: 9,0%. mais passons. La bière est bonne, bien épicée, la couleur brune est douce aux yeux. lalcool ne se fait pas trop sentir et sest tant mieux. léquilibre est parfait et les épices..wow.

Bottled. An unlcear deep red beer with a thin brown head. The aroma is very spicy with notes of anise and corriander as well as notes of oranges. The flavor is also very spicy again anise and coriander are the strongest on a very sweet back ground with strong notes of caramel, leading to a dry spicy finish. Thanks David, Rastacouere, for bringing this to Denmark.

Dereks bottle.  I have enjoyed every member of the Vobiscum lineup, the Priest Made Me Do It! representation of the brewerys offerings.  Dark brown and an off-brown slightly bubbly head, with coco aroma.  Rich malting, creamy mouthfeel.  On the sweet side, very good Belgium.
Bottle. Reddish dark amber colour with a huge white head. Aroma of anis and pepper. Very tasty flavour of anis-root with a caramel notes. Very nice and tasty.

Very dark ruby in colour, large long lasting off-white coloured head, great lacing.  The aroma is yeasty, lots of bananas, dark fruits, some light chocolate, earthy, moderate sweetness.  The flavour is full and creamy, fruity, lots of yeast, more bananas, some chocolate, spice, good sweetness, dark fruits.  Creamy mouthfeel, medium body, high carbonation.  Finishes long, lightly bitter, gassy.  A great beer from a great brewery.
500ml bottle from <a
href=http://www.ratebeer.com/Place/quebec/v target=blank>Métro Joannette in Verdun, Quebec for $3.99.
Purchased on December 28, 2006 and opened on March 2, 2007
No best before date.
BIF from Goldorak. very dark brown with a big fluffy head. Fruit, earth and yeast aroma with a hint of banana chips. Dusty very spicy flavour. Meaty banana. Light chocolate note.

(Bottle)  Pours a mahogany body with a large beige head.  Aroma of plum, coriander, orange, ginger, and some other herbs.   Flavor of licorice, dark fruit, toasted malt, grape candy, cinnamon, and other spices.

Bottle at papsoes pre-festival tasting. Red brown colour with a beige head. Aroma is fruit, alcohol, dried fruits , malt, spices. Flavour is fruit, dried fruit, spices, roasted, malt. A nice pleasent beer.

UPDATED: DEC 16, 2007 Bottle at papsoes pre-festival tasting. Clear, copper-red body with a beige head. Tea-notes, malt and spices in the nose. The flavor has cardamom, ginger and maybe some other spices, as well as sweetness and a little roastiness. Full, sweet mouthfeel. Sweet and spiced finish. A nice one. (070510)

(Bottle 50 cl) Courtesy of Rastacouere. Hazy, reddish amber golden with a dense, beige head. Very spicy aroma - anise I believe. Fairly full-bodied with lots of roasted malt, sweetish licorice notes and other spices - camomile? Very subdued bitterness. Pleasant. 090507

Bouteille. Mousse très forte, qui devient mince et trace bien le verre. Couleur brun opaque. Arôme très épicé et poivrée. Goût bien épicé plus complexe (poivre encore ici), avec notes florales bien présentes, et dagrumes (orange). Finale en alcool et malt torréfié. Effervescence moyenne. Cette bière est TRÈS bonne.

Sample at April 2007 Brewnosers meeting. Dark amber colour with a frothy off-white head. Big licorice aroma, light citrus and spicy notes. Light licorice, brown sugar, herbal flavours. Medium bodied, lightly silky and lightly fizzy mouthfeel. Another solid offering from these guys.

Pours a clear brown color with a thick bubbly beige head that leaves nice lacing on the glass. The aroma has a strong licorice feel with spices. The flavor is pretty good with its licorice - spices combo but the malt is also noteworthy with its round and rich qualities. The body is medium to full with a creamy texture and gentle carbonation. Another superb offering from this excellent brewery.
Bottle,500 ml. Clear brown color tan head that rapidly fade. Aroma of sweet spice (coriander) and fake banana candy. Quite soft taste the same as the aroma sligth bitterness in the end. Bof...

Bottle: Poured a deep burgundy brown color ale with a big foamy head with great retention and lacing. Aroma of anis is totally dominating but still well back by some strong malt. Taste is dominating by anis with some candi sugar. I thought the anis was a bit overwhelming and could have been more balance. Body was above average and alcohol was well hidden. Nicely done overall but a better calibration of spices would bring this to world class level.

Bouteille de 500 ml achetée à La Cave à Bières (Saint-Jovite, QC). Arôme: Odeur dépices, de réglisse noire et  de caramel au beurre. Apparence: La couleur est brune opaque. Présence dun large col beige mousseux avec une large dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Goût dépices, de caramel avec une pointe dagrumes. Durée moyenne de larrière goût. Palette: Le corps est plein avec une texture crémeuse. Moyenne effervescence en bouche. Légère présence de raisin en arrière goût. (Rating #855)

UPDATED: AUG 12, 2008 Rerate: Orange citrus and sweet malts are grounded pleasantly by grainy caereal notes in the nose.  A touch of alcohol is also apparent.  Clear dark brown body is topped by a generous and lasting tan, fine bubbled, dense head that laces well and lasts throughout.  Tangy citrus character keeps the big round sweetness of the malts from becoming cloying.  Bread dough like yeast character and some hints of alcohol especially in the finish.  Medium full body with strong effervescence that stops just short of becoming sharp.  A lesson in contrasts and a definite improvement over the last time i sampled it.  Tulip glass.  Cellar temperature.  Bottle (Rahman, Jun-08).   Original Rating (7-2-6-2-12=2.9): Strong bitter orange and coriander spiciness greet the nose along with some round, sweet malt character.  Plenty of chunky yeast in suspension in the otherwise fairly clear, deep brown body that is topped by a low, large bubbled, partial cover of tan head.  Strong chocolate and orange flavours with spices that battle the mild bitterness.  Sweetness is somewhat cloying and alcohol is fairly notable.  Medium body with doughy texture and somewhat low carbonation.  Bottle sampled at the post-Mondial tasting 2006.

Bottle shared with HogTownHarry, GregClow, jerc, mds & tupalev -- courtesy of tupalev. Pours a clear ruby-brown with a small diminishing off-white head. Interesting aroma of spices, licorice, toffee, malt and yeast. Flavour: wow, thats a little odd, I dont like it as much as the aroma but its still good: Sweet malt, spices, yeast, licorice and dark fruit -- a little boozy but not overly so. Medium bodied. Quite a unique beer, I liked it.

Bottle. Pours a cherry-mahogany coloured body with floaties and a small off-white head. The aroma is quite interesting with lots of spice, licorice, cinnamon, toffee, and butterscotch. Soft malty body - cereal type grains, spicey licorice, and caramel dark malts. I found the aroma to be a lot nicer than the flavour. Still nice though.

Bottle shared with blankboy, HogTownHarry, jerc, tupalev & mds - courtesy of tupalev. Deep ruby-brown with a small mocha head. Interesting aroma mixing dark fruit juice, licorice, spices (nutmeg? clove?) and a hint of yeast. Flavour - nice! Sweet, fruity malt to start, warming in the middle, turning roastier as it warms, with a spicey, peppery finish. Fantastic!

Bottle shared with the regular crew including MDS, courtesy of myself.  Really interesting aroma:  sweet candy, incense, yeast, licorice, and lots of floral notes - I loved it.  Dark brown, foamy thick brownish head.  Nice taste:  lots of spicy dark malt, soft floral notes, and some alcohol.  Wonderful spicy finish.  Complex and a unique take on the style.  Outstanding.

Bottle. Dark brown body, moderate tan head and lacing. Big interesting aroma, various fruits, light anise and root notes. Bit of bitterness to the flavour, sweet malt middle with dry anise bite to the finish that lingers. Thin for the style.  Pretty interesting, but lacks the coherence needed to transcend the average.

UPDATED: AUG 20, 2006 Bottle (500ml).  Shared with blankboy, GregClow, jerc, mds and tupalev, blankboys bottle.  Clear deep ruby with a decent foamy beige head.  Complex, unique aroma - anise, toffee malt, various fruits like apricot and plum, quite yeasty with a virtual miasma of sweet pungent spices blending with the malt, I got more apple character as it warmed.  The taste was a little more straightforward, very thick sweet brown sugar malt, sweet spices, plentiful yeast, fruity but oddly no anise in the flavour - alcohol bitterness emerges in the finish.  Nice thick body, sticky mouthfeel with an acceptable liveliness, slightly alcoholic and a hint of astringency from all the spice - a really good dubbel, nice and malty - one of the better brews of the tasting for my money.

A brown ale with nice mahogany hues and an extra thick light moka head. In aroma, wonderful candy sugar mix in with orange pulp with notes of nutmeg. In mouth, a ricjh alcohol gives way to a sweet candy malt, with hints of choclate, nutmeg,  and oranges. Slightly nutty notes. An excellent offering from Fred. Bottle bought at Joanette, May 2006.

This is a strange tasting double not similar to a belgian double.  The bottle I had in Montreal was very acidic both in smell and taste.  Maybe this bottle was bad but the acidic taste was so prominent that it made what should be a smooth malty ale more difficult to drink.
Robe brune légèrement voilée surmontée dune mousse beige épaisse qui sestompe. Arômes de métal et de caramel. Saveurs dagrumes, de caramel et dalcool.

Cloudy dark brown hue, with a tan-colored head, but falling quickly, the nose is one of dark dried fruits of plums, raisins, figs, with a candied orange peels note, with some cinnamon, nutmeg and anise spiciness, hint of dark coffee, roasted and caramelized malts in the aroma follows through on a medium-bodied palate with an acidic candied tangerine skin character, caramelized and roasted malts, with a hint of molasses, anise spiciness, orange peels fruitiness, leading towards a mild bitter chocolate, and a slight burt toast roastiness finish.

Post-Mondial tasting at Goldoraks pad, from 500 ml bottle(s).  Hazy mahogany with a bit of lasting brown head....lots of spice in the nose, almost an overload, with anise and allspice and orange peel all strutting their stuff, to the point where the fine caramel malt seems to be crying out to be noticed....on the tongue a two-part adventure, with thick sweet near-syrupy caramel at the front quickly dissipating as huge fiery spices, ginger and more anise and Mexican chocoalte show up....creamy, soft carbonation and a remarkably long, lingering finish with the spices staying with you as long as seems possible....

Aroma:Dark fruit,plum,malt caramel,licorice....
Appearance:Dark brown,light head...
Flavor:alcohol,very licorice and anise,caramel,light citrus flavor....
Good

Bottle. Dark brown muddy body with average carbonation and a thin beige bubbly head. Awesome malty aroma with fruity (plum, grape, strawberry, citrus) notes. Texture is smooth and taste hides the alcohol very well. Aside the malty and hoppy flavors, it carries yeasty and fruity hints as well. Ends with a decently warming finish. Another more than enjoyable beer from Charlevoix. Thanks PrimeMinister for that sample!

UPDATED: AUG 27, 2007 Brown bottle, 500 ml, 9 %, date dachat : June 7 2006; eye: brown with shades of burgundy and orange, beige head made up of small bubbles that disapper rapidely, full of little bubbles after it was poured but that disappears rapidly, no effervescence nor lacing; nose: anis, balloon that you blow in for kids party (?!?), cocoa powder; mouth: smooth, velvety, despite the high alcohol content it is not apparent except for a little peppery appearance in the finale, "balloon for kids party (?!?)", fizzy, lightly sweet and very lightly bitter, medium to full body; overall: special

FRANÇAIS

Bouteille brune, 500 ml, date dachat : 7 juin 2006; oeil : brune avec des dégradés bourgogne et orange, mousse beige formée de petites builles qui saffaise rapidement, pleins de petites bulles sur la paroi du verre mais ceux-ci disparaissent assez rapidement, pas deffervescence ni de dentelle; nez : anis, balloune quon souffle pour les fêtes denfants (?!?), poudre de cacao; bouche : tout doux, velouté, on ne sent pas la présence de lalcool sauf pour une petite pointe poivrée en finale, anis, « balloune quon souffle pour les fêtes denfant (?!?) », pétillante, légèrement sucrée et très légèrement amère, corps moyen à complet; en résumé : spéciale

UPDATED: OCT 28, 2009 Licorice, star anise, and allspice burst from the glass like a meteor spice shower...Coriander and orange blossoms dally above cocoa powder, propelled by active, fitting carbonation...Roastiness and alcohol tingle in the back, helped by some frolicking black pepper, all together dissolving some of the spicy sweetness...This candy sweet concoction isnt your typical Abbey Dubbel at all, more of a relative to the superb Pannepot, but it will most probably please the sweet child in you...
Post-mondial Tasting. Très beau brun, beau collet. Arome dépice sucré, réglisse noir. Bon goût de réglisse malté, très doux. Bravo!

Initially light beige head has difficulty to stay on place and leaves a hazy dark brown-mahogany colored body. Pleasant mouthfeel has a certain airy character from the small and compact bubbles, yet keeps a good roundness and creaminess from the excellent malt extraction. In terms of flavors, it takes some time and warming up to develop fully, but once that is done, it is an explosion of anise that is quickly joined by prunes, figs and cherries/blackberries though it has nowhere near the fruit concentration I expected, namely thick flavors of dates and grapes. It remains all through surprisingly dry, perhaps it did attenuate fast after the bottling. Vague hints of powdery chocolate support this relatively low profile sweetness. Seems to still be hiding a bit of its potential and complexity.
